blocks.name: cldgis
blocks.content: The leading ideal sequence used in the Hilbert Basis Theorem.

blocks.name: df-ldgis
blocks.content: Define a function which carries polynomial ideals to the sequence of coefficient ideals of leading coefficients of degree- ` x ` elements in the polynomial ideal. The proof that this map is strictly monotone is the core of the Hilbert Basis Theorem ~ hbt . (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 31-Mar-2015.)
blocks.origin:
axiom df-ldgis(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  |- wceq(cldgis, cmpt(s0, universe, cmpt(s1, cfv(clidl, cfv(cpl1, cv(s0))), cmpt(s2, cn0, cab(s3, wrex(s4, cv(s1), wa(wbr(cfv(cfv(cdg1, cv(s0)), cv(s4)), cle, cv(s2)), wceq(cv(s3), cfv(cfv(cco1, cv(s4)), cv(s2))))))))))
  -| diffss(s1, s3)
  -| diffss(s1, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffss(s3, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s3)
  -| diffss(s2, s3)
  -| diffss(s0, s4)
  -| diffss(s2, s4)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
}
blocks.pretty:
axiom df-ldgis(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, setvar s3, setvar s4) {
  ‚ä¢ ldgIdlSeq =(s0 ‚àà ùïå ‚Ü¶(s1 ‚àà(LIdeal `(Poly1 ` s0))‚Ü¶(s2 ‚àà ‚Ñï0 ‚Ü¶ { s3 | ‚àÉ(s4 ‚àà s1,(((deg1 ` s0)` s4)[‚â§]s2 ‚àß s3 =((coe1 ` s4)` s2)))})))
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s1)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, s2)
  ‚ä£ d(s3, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s3)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s2, s4)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, s2)
}

blocks.name: hbtlem1
blocks.content: Value of the leading coefficient sequence function. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 31-Mar-2015.)

  ‚ä¢ ((c0 ‚àà c1 ‚àß c2 ‚àà c3 ‚àß c4 ‚àà ‚Ñï0)‚Üí((c5 ` c2)` c4)= { s0 | ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,((c6 ` s1)[‚â§]c4 ‚àß s0 =((coe1 ` s1)` c4)))})

  ‚ä£ c3 =(LIdeal ` c7)
  ‚ä£ c5 =(ldgIdlSeq ` c0)
  ‚ä£ c6 =(deg1 ` c0)

  ‚ä£ d(s0, c2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c4)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c0)
  ‚ä£ d(s1, c2)

} = {
  3eqtrd(((c5 ` c2)` c4), { s0 | ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,((c6 ` s1)[‚â§]c4 ‚àß s0 =((coe1 ` s1)` c4)))}, (((hs0 ‚àà c3 ‚Ü¶(hs1 ‚àà ‚Ñï0 ‚Ü¶ { s0 | ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà hs0,((c6 ` s1)[‚â§]hs1 ‚àß s0 =((coe1 ` s1)` hs1)))}))` c2)` c4), ((hs1 ‚àà ‚Ñï0 ‚Ü¶ { s0 | ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà c2,((c6 ` s1)[‚â§]hs1 ‚àß s0 =((coe1 ` s1)` hs1)))})` c4), (c0 ‚àà c1 ‚àß c2 ‚àà c3 ‚àß c4 ‚àà ‚Ñï0))
  3ad2ant1(c0 ‚àà c1, c2 ‚àà c3, c4 ‚àà ‚Ñï0, ((c5 ` c2)` c4)=(((hs0 ‚àà c3 ‚Ü¶(hs1 ‚àà ‚Ñï0 ‚Ü¶ { s0 | ‚àÉ(s1 ‚àà hs0,((c6 ` s1)[‚â§]hs1 ‚àß s0 =((coe1 ` s1)` hs1)))}))` c2)` c4))

blocks.name: hbtlem6
blocks.content: There is a finite set of polynomials matching any single stage of the image. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 1-Apr-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm hbtlem6(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4, class c5, class c6, wff w0) {
  |- wi(w0, wrex(s0, cin(cpw(c0), cfn), wss(cfv(cfv(c1, c0), c2), cfv(cfv(c1, cfv(c3, cv(s0))), c2))))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cpl1, c5))
  -| wceq(c6, cfv(clidl, c4))
  -| wceq(c1, cfv(cldgis, c5))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(crsp, c4))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c5, clnr))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c0, c6))
  -| wi(w0, wcel(c2, cn0))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c5)
  -| diffsw(s0, w0)
} = {
  mpd(w0, wrex(s0, cin(cpw(c0), cfn), wss(cfv(cfv(c1, c0), c2), cfv(cfv(c1, cfv(c3, cv(s0))), c2))), wrex(hs0, cin(cpw(cfv(cfv(c1, c0), c2)), cfn), wceq(cfv(cfv(c1, c0), c2), cfv(cfv(crsp, c5), cv(hs0)))))
  syl2anc(w0, wrex(hs0, cin(cpw(cfv(cfv(c1, c0), c2)), cfn), wceq(cfv(cfv(c1, c0), c2), cfv(cfv(crsp, c5), cv(hs0)))), wcel(c5, clnr), wcel(cfv(cfv(c1, c0), c2), cfv(clidl, c5)))
  syl3anc(w0, wcel(cfv(cfv(c1, c0), c2), cfv(clidl, c5)), wcel(c5, crg), wcel(c0, c6), wcel(c2, cn0))

blocks.content: The Hilbert Basis Theorem - the ring of univariate polynomials over a Noetherian ring is a Noetherian ring. (Contributed by Stefan O'Rear, 4-Apr-2015.)
